Articles.Content:
Hi all

I am working on my first interplanetary design in my new sandbox game, in which I take a "not on my watch"-approach to loosing Kerbals. As you can see from my signature this has so far been successful. It just mean I try to plan carefully and test as much as possible before actually putting kerbals at risk. However, it does not seem appropriate to send an entire empty ship to Duna, so I need to plan this a bit more carefully. And I need your help on how to look through these numbers and see if they match up with requirements. I'm not a rocket scientist afterall, and not that comfortable interpreting the Kerbal Engineer Redux readouts. Comments are welcome.

A prerequisite for my design was to use the larger command pods. It seemed unrealistic to send single-man pods on interplanetary missions, so no Mk1 pods. In addition, I decided to make a crew cabin a requirement for extended operations, so both the orbiter and the lander must include a crew cabin. It was just a very simple way to simulate some sort of life support requirement.

The ship can be roughly divided into three parts: the lander, the orbiter, and the transfer stage. The combined multipart ship, called Duna Endeavour, will start out from a 100km Kerbin orbit. The transfer stage will bring the entire craft from Kerbin to a 53km Duna orbit. The lander, called Duna Explorer, will bring two kerbals to the surface of Duna and later return them to the orbiter via a seperate ascent stage. The orbiter, called Duna Orbiter, will keep a single kerbal in orbit during the visit, and later bring all three kerbals back to Kerbin. So, a classical apollo-style approach.

Mods used: various KSPX tanks, and the 1-4 adapter for the transfer stage rocket mounting. I have made a personal modification to integrate MechJeb functionality into the stock command pods, so that should not be a prerequisite mod to load the craft. Kerbal Engineering Redux, obviously, but only used during design.

The transfer stage - PICTURE

The stage has an initial TWR of 0.11 making it rather slow to accelerate. It worries me that maneuvers might become difficult to execute accurately. The good part is that it prevents wobbling. It has a delta-v capacity of 4364km/s.

The lander - PICTURE, PICTURE (ascent)

The lander has a TWR of 1.47, and a delta-v capacity of 2547km/s. The landing will rely heavily on parachutes, with two drogue chutes and four main chutes. It is divided into a lower descent stage and an upper ascent stage. The descent stage contains a mixture of fuel tanks (306/374 fuel/oxid), which is hopefully sufficient for the deorbit and landing burns. The descent stage will be left behind during ascent, and therefore contains all the unnecessary equipment, like landing gears, landing lights, floodlights, sensors, crew cabin, solar arrays. The ascent stage will be topped up with fuel from the descent stage before launch, and will return the crew to the 53km orbit and rendezvous and dock with the orbiter.

The orbiter - PICTURE

The orbiter has a TWR of 0.94, and a delta-v capacity of 6976km/s.

Now, for those curious about how I got this into orbit, then: I didn't. At least not in this specific configuration. The four-engine arrangement on the transfer stage does not allow it to be placed on top of a lifter. So I will use hyperedit to bring this design into orbit. However, I *did* do it with an identical design except for a single LV-NB atomic rocket from the KSPX package. The transfer/orbiter parts were launched together as a single payload and the lander seperately and docked in orbit. To launch the transfer/orbiter payload I first had to drain all tanks by an extended burn while still clasped to the platform, and subsequently top of all tanks via six refuelling missions. It was doable.

Questions

1. Is the transfer stage powerful enough to bring the craft from a 100km Kerbin orbit to a 53km Duna orbit (aerobrake-assisted)? If not, I hope the orbiter can compensate without compromising the rest of the mission.

2. Does the descent stage seem to contain adequate fuel for deorbit and a parachute-assisted landing?

3. Is the ascent stage powerful enough to launch into a 53km Duna orbit?

4. Is the orbiter powerful enough to return from a 53km Duna orbit to Kerbin reentry?

5. Is any of the modules overpowered?

6. What is the weakest part of this design?

7. Where is the easiest place to upload a craft file?

Edited May 29, 2013 by jeti140973

Well, you are certainly in the "overkill" area. With 4+ km/s on your transfer stage, you don't really need to aerobrake to get to low Duna orbit with fuel to spare. Likewise the almost 7 km/s of the orbiter are "a bit" too much: With a bit more than one you can do a Duna-Kerbin transfer. The only place where you are a bit light in excess delta-v is the lander. If you spend a lot to brake before landing (I mean, if you are awful at landing, because it's also a bit overkill), you may run short on ascent. However, you could just give legs to the orbiter and take it down to rescue the kerbals, in that case, it has the delta-v to do so.

All in all, this mission could go on a diet. But, it will do the job, and allow mistakes, that's for sure.

Rune. Hope you find it useful.

I do find it useful, thanks. And yes, I guess it is overpowered (and as if that wasn't enough, sorry for multiplying all delta-vs by a thousand btw ), but I intend to reuse the design for some of the other planets as well, so that might come in handy. I am also considering to attach additional "deadweight" like probes and rovers to the craft if I can find a suitable place for it. I believe the low TWR would prevent the orbiter from doing a landing - or a takeoff, at least. I think I will remove the four droptanks on the orbiter, and see if that helps. But yeah... who doesn't like to have some extra fuel onboard? Just in case something goes kerbal...
